document_title: Skin cancer: Signs, causes and diagnosis
subsection_content:
To diagnose skin cancer, the most common methods are a general health examination and personal and family medical history. The doctor can then evaluate the lesions using dermoscopy, biopsy, and histopathological evaluation.
A biopsy is the removal of a small amount of tissue to examine under a microscope. The suspected skin lesion is removed, usually after a local anesthetic is used to numb the area. The doctor also often removes an area of ​​healthy tissue around the lesion.
The sample removed during the biopsy is then analyzed to determine if it is skin cancer. Doctors will then evaluate the cells, tissues, and organs to diagnose the disease.
